The impact mitigation features of a modern car are tested to a speed of 40kph. Above that, you are on your own. So technically, its a matter of choice: do you want to be 60kph dead or 100kph dead?

In practice a more massive vehicle does not make you safer on the road, because your stopping distance is longer and therefore your opportunity to avoid a collision is shorter. In addition, SUV type vehicles have a high centre of gravity making them prone to roll over. In addition, the suspension of a true off road 4WD is not suitable for turning at speed.

Rolling over in an SUV is bad because the vehicle is too heavy for the driver cabin and can easily crush under its own weight. For this reason, stopping distance under different road conditions , the only relevant factor for gauging a vehicle's occupant safety. In other words, being safe on the road is about avoiding collisions, not surviving collisions.

Two car collisions are not a reliable model to gauge the relative safety of a vehicle, because most road collisions are single vehicle crashes into stationary objects.

Just a few fun facts as a table tennis player: since 2014/2015 we stopped using celluloid balls. Instead, now the balls are made of plastic with a diameter of at least 40 mm (hence they are referred to as 40+). Also, the majority are now seamless which means they got rid of the weak point where the two halves would converge. The grading of the ball also matters. If you're using a 3 star ball which is much rounder than, let's say a 1 star (training ball), you get more stability, spin and speed due to less friction. The brand matters too - nitakku balls feel heavier than others, for insntace.
I doubt this will trigger an update for the video:)) but I hope you enjoyed the quick fun facts.

Hi ... I liked your video. However, I think there is a small misunderstanding in min 07:20 when you talk about the inconvenience of having a car made out of rubber. You argue that after the collision the spring back velocity will be very high and you relate this to the effect of acceleration in the human body.
In reality, when you have an elastic material the impact duration is larger and the peak load and therefore the acceleration is smaller. The real problem of using a very elastic material is the protection of the occupants since there will be very higher deformations in the cabin that could harm the people inside.

Why is this all predicated on ping pong balls? No explanation, no discussion, no consideration for other projectiles.

The main learning point of all the NCAP tests is that crumple zones and airbags only go so far. In a collision (let's say with a concrete wall) driving at 40mph or less, there's a pretty good chance that you escape entirely uninjured. In fact, many cars just won't deploy the airbags at speeds lower than 35-30mph because there's no benefit to doing so (seat belts being adequate at those speeds), but airbag deployment does carry risks of injury.

At speeds above 50mph (again, concrete wall collision, or head on with another car carrying the same momentum) the momentum change is too great, thus car safety systems stand little chance of saving your life. The "goldie-locks" zone between 40 and 50 mph is where airbags, seat belt pretensioners, well designed crumple zones and other crash safety features decide the difference between life and death. That's also where things like how you hold the wheel or whether, as a passenger, you rest your legs on the dashboard can make a crucial difference.

The energy represented by the chocolate would get repurposed pretty fast around here. #The Tollhouse Principle.

On the comments about bigger cars being safer, bigger cars also handle quite poorly compared to smaller ones, so in a pinch you have much less margin for error, making it much more likely to actually be involved in a collision.

Some have handling characteristics I would deem woefully inadequate. I'm talking about SUVs which have a tendency to roll if you swerve... like you would if you were about to hit something or someone. Also big pick up trucks with poorly designed suspension which tend to enter various modes of resonance when excited by a bump at cruising speeds (50-80mph). The body and suspension resonance bands appear to have some overlap, so in the right conditions body oscillations will readily couple to the suspension and the two oscillators will just feed each other until something gives...

As far as being safer in a collision, that, I suppose, depends on what you crash into. I tend to defer to NCAP and their American equivalents, but it doesn't look very good there either.

I'd say you're safest in something that in a pinch can get you out of trouble. Also don't settle for anything less than a 5 star safety rating.

The welt left by the ping pong ball on that professor's stomach reminded me a lot about the welts left behind after a hit with a paintball gun. Those little suckers typically travel at about 250 feet per second (170 mph) which is about the typical limit of paintball arenas for safety reasons. They are 68 caliber (0.68 inches) projectiles with a typical mass of about 3.0 grams. A ping pong ball, somewhat surprisingly to me, has a mass of about 2.7 grams which is almost that of the paintball but it is traveling much faster with the vacuum cannon.

EDIT: BTW, it is terribly illegal and absolutely dangerous to fire a FROZEN paintball at someone with a paintball gun, effectively turning into a .68 caliber slug. That's a pretty good illustration about the drastic effects of the material composition of the projectile. Something that can easily fragment and filled with a lightly viscous fluid is far less damaging than an effectively solid object despite having the same mass.

11:45 Maybe it's good to clarify what a "G" is, for the unaware viewer; 4700 Gs is a big number, but if someone were to ask you "what does that mean, 4700 Gs?", you'd probably want to be able to explain what it means. Let's go Mark Rober style, here:

So, imagine a 1 kg (approx. 2 lbs) packet of sugar being dropped from a tower (say, 44 meters) with the packet sufficiently streamlined to not experience much air resistance. Let's measure the velocity of that packet of sugar every second.
The moment we drop it, we know its velocity is still 0 m/s. What does that mean? It means that, if we magically turned off gravity, the packet would seem to float at the same height forever. (We now turn gravity on again.) After 1 second, the packet has sped up and is falling at 9.81 m/s (let's round that to 10 m/s from here on out): that means that, if we were to turn off gravity again, the packet would this time keep falling instead of hovering in place, but it would not keep falling faster and faster. It would move down at a constant velocity as if somebody were lowering it with a rope, and it would traverse about 10 meters every second. If we looked at the packet after 2 seconds of having experienced gravity, it would be falling at 19.62 m/s (about 20 m/s), and after 3 seconds, 29.43 m/s (about 30 m/s). Coincidentally, that's also when the packet reaches the ground of the 44 meter-high tower.


As you might notice, our packet's velocity - remember, that's the constant distance it would be traversing every second if we turned off gravity - keeps increasing per second by about 10 m/s. We say that it "accelerates at 9.81 m/s²", and we call that number "g", the "gravitational acceleration on Earth" (close to sea level).
Now, if we dropped a 2 kg packet, it would obviously be falling way faster after 1 second. To be precise, it would fall twice as fast, at about 20 m/s. After 2 seconds, it would fall at about 40 m/s, and so on.
If we lived on an Earth where gravity was twice as strong, our original 1 kg packet would speed up during its fall as much as the 2 kg packet does on our own Earth. Key insight: when speeding up due to gravity, we can compare how hard the force of gravity pulls per kg, with the acceleration it's giving per kg. This is why you'll see "g" expressed as a measure of "force per mass", because, although it's a handy number to use for acceleration, it's also handy to describe the force of gravity (in units of N/kg, but humans have no good reference of what a Newton of force is, unlike of velocity).


So, if someone tells you something causes "4700 g of force", what they mean is that, if you imagined that the described force (in Diana's example: air-pushing-force) was gravity acting on a 1 kg packet of sugar on some outer-space Earth, that outer-space Earth would make a tiny 1 kg packet of sugar speed up as fast as our Earth speeds up a whopping 4700 kg. Yes: it would be an outer-space Earth where our 1 kg packet of sugar would reach the ground as fast as a pickup truck would back here on Earth (although you have no good reference of this, because when people drop pickup trucks, the bottom acts like a sail and thus the truck falls way slower than it would without air), which is in approximately 0.044 seconds - 5 of those could happen in the span of one blink!

Solid rubber? I can tell you, for absolute certain, not. There's a reason that tires are inflated. A solid-rubber tire actually makes for a much rougher ride. No, you need that air cushion to absorb the force of the impact.

"People have looked into banning large cars from city centers because of this physics."
Let's not lose sight of the fact that city centers tend to be extraordinarily harder to maneuver one's way around with a larger vehicle.

"I think we all have a sense that driving a bigger car is safer, but-"
Well hang on, there. Yes, a larger vehicle is likely to come through a collision with less damage, and will probably be less costly to repair, but a smaller vehicle is less likely to get into a collision in the first place.
Have you done this experiment with the can still full of soda?
Did not expect a moment from The IT Crowd would happen in real life

The truth is, a bigger, heavier car is only safer in an accident against a smaller car. But for any car, the smaller and lighter the better regarding security. Less inertia so easier braking and turning to avoid the crash, quicker response time, more predictable and controllable reactions when moving the wheel violently, less energy to dissipate if the crash is unavoidable. And if more and more drivers get big cars, the advantage of safety against smaller cars disappear because everybody else has a big car too.

A lighter car can have as good passive security as a big car may have, but will always have better active security because of physics :)

Slight miscalculation in the video. A bouncy (tennisball) impact with a heavy object going the same speed will result in a delta-V of 4 times the initial speed.
So Fiat 80km/h (not bouncy) to wall (0km/h) -> delta V 80km/h.
fiat80-fiat80 -> deltaV 80km/h.
fiat80-SUV80 -> deltaV almost 160km/h
tennisball80-wall0 -> deltaV almost 160km/h
tennisball160-wall0 -> deltaV almost 320km/h
tennisball80-SUV80-> deltaV almost 320km/h
The last two are the same, just a change of frame-of-reference.
